questions.question: What is the main difference between supervised and unsupervised learning?
options: Supervised learning is faster than unsupervised learning
Supervised learning uses labeled data, unsupervised learning doesn't
Unsupervised learning is more accurate than supervised learning
Supervised learning only works with numerical data
questions.explanation: The main difference is that supervised learning uses labeled training data (input-output pairs), while unsupervised learning works with unlabeled data to find hidden patterns.

questions.question: Which algorithm is commonly used for linear regression?
questions.explanation: Gradient descent is commonly used to optimize the parameters in linear regression by minimizing the cost function through iterative updates.

questions.question: What is overfitting in machine learning?
options: When a model performs poorly on training data
When a model learns the training data too well and fails to generalize
When a model takes too long to train
When a model uses too many features
questions.explanation: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well, including noise and outliers, and fails to generalize to new, unseen data.

questions.question: Which metric is used to evaluate classification models?
questions.explanation: Accuracy is a common metric for classification models, measuring the proportion of correct predictions out of total predictions.

questions.question: What is the purpose of cross-validation?
options: To reduce the size of the dataset
To assess model performance and prevent overfitting
questions.explanation: Cross-validation is used to assess model performance and prevent overfitting by training and testing the model on different subsets of the data.

questions.question: Which clustering algorithm requires you to specify the number of clusters beforehand?
questions.explanation: K-means clustering requires you to specify the number of clusters (k) beforehand, unlike other algorithms that can determine the optimal number automatically.

questions.question: What is feature scaling and why is it important?
options: Making features have the same scale to prevent some features from dominating
Removing unnecessary features from the dataset
Adding new features to improve model performance
Converting categorical features to numerical ones
questions.explanation: Feature scaling ensures all features have the same scale, preventing features with larger ranges from dominating the model and improving algorithm performance.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of unsupervised learning?
questions.explanation: Customer segmentation is an example of unsupervised learning, where we group customers based on their behavior without knowing the 'correct' segments beforehand.

questions.question: What does the term 'bias' refer to in machine learning?
options: The error introduced by approximating a real-world problem
The difference between predicted and actual values
questions.explanation: Bias refers to the error introduced by approximating a real-world problem with a simplified model, leading to systematic errors in predictions.

questions.question: Which Python library is most commonly used for machine learning?
questions.explanation: Scikit-learn is the most commonly used Python library for machine learning, providing a wide range of algorithms and tools for data mining and analysis.
